top_comment.text:
From what I've heard, getting kicked in the balls can definitely hurt like 
hell. It sounds like the immediate pain lasts only a short while, but can 
still ache for a couple of hours. 

As bad as that is, I would still say childbirth sounds a LOT worse. Pain 
meds aren't always available or an option (allergies to medications), and 
they only last a short while. Have you ever seen a woman giving birth? 
She's beet red, covered in sweat, her veins are bulging, and she's shitting 
herself without even noticing it. All the muscles in her abdomen are 
straining and cramping trying to force something the size of a watermelon 
out of a hole the size of an egg, and her perineum (the skin between her 
vagina and anus) often tears during the whole thing, again without her 
noticing it. Depending on the individual woman, labour can last anywhere 
from a few hours to a few days. If all goes well, she has to stay in the 
hospital for at least a couple of days, and it takes a year for her body to 
recover from the trauma of the whole thing. 

Some women even die in childbirth, but I've never heard of a man die from 
being kicked in the balls. Not saying it never happens or that it isn't 
extremely painful, but it must be extremely rare (I tried searching it on 
google and found nothing). Meanwhile, hundreds of thousands of women die 
every year during childbirth.﻿

comments.text:
Key word at the end of the article: *quanitfy.*

*"it will be some time yet before physicians can quantify physical pain at 
the clinical setting."*

In other words, they found something that could prove worthy in terms of 
measuring physical pain because it removes the pain an individual may also 
be feeling emotionally and seems to coincide with the use of pain killers, 
indicating it is indeed physical pain. But it still cannot be quantified. 
That's the problem with fibromyalgia patients for example: you can't 
quantify their pain from one subject to another, you can only conclude they 
do indeed feel physical pain. That last sentence being key. 

Now seriously, let's end this here. I get what you're trying to say but the 
other part of your logic working against you is I really don't think ASAP 
Sci really gives a shit what people think about science and sugar coating 
it, they just report science for what it is and what they see and can 
measure and *quantify.* I just thought it was a fun video.

of pain.

because a female is willing to have a second child doesn't mean that the 
pain couldn't be as bad or worse than a man's. Getting kicked in the balls 
doesn't amount to anything, so of course you wouldn't willingly volunteer 
to go through that. However, sometimes having a 2nd child, or for your 
child to have siblings is totally worth the pain.

I'd also like to suggest that females might have it much worse because 
before having to give birth, you have to carry a child for 9 months while 
going through massive body and hormonal changes. As ASAPSCI talked about in 
the Heartbreak video, emotional feelings such as hormonal 
depression/heartbreak trigger the same region in the brain as physical 
pain. I'm not arguing that women go through intense pain like childbirth 
for 9months+ --that's ridiculous. I'm just saying that through childbirth, 
pregnancy, and monthly periods, women never catch a break! So who has it 
worse again? ;)

Length of pain and the peak point of pain are two different things. Just 
because something lasts for much longer, it doesn't mean that it hurts 
more. That is like saying a paper cut in between your finger that annoys 
you for a few days hurts more than a twisted nipple which only hurts for a 
couple minutes or so. And plus, women, under normal circumstances, are 
drugged and expecting. Getting hit in the junk is usually unexpected and 
without any medication to numb the pain. Not even adrenaline is that fast. 

The next argument is that it is (again under normal circumstances) a choice 
to give birth. Why would women go through the pain of child birth if it is 
a.) easier to adopt, and b.) as painful as everyone claims. 

And if you DO want to talk about pain time-wise, guys spend their ENTIRE 
LIVES protecting that area. Getting hit in the nether region can happen at 
any moment, on any day, at any age. Think about that for a moment.

Finally, giving birth is natural. A woman's body is created to give birth. 
This means it has some level of preparing itself for the pain to come. Or 
at least, more so than a man getting hit in the groin. 

Final accusation: As far as highest point of pain, the guys win that 
argument. As far as the experience OVERALL PAIN the women no doubt have it 
harder.

comments.text:
"how is getting hit in the junk less natural"
Our bodies are made for reproduction, therefore women are meant to give 
birth while men are meant to impregnate women to allow them to give birth. 
In order to do that, the reproductive organs are meant to be kept safe. If 
they are not, then that may cause a man to become sterile which is not 
natural.

"Pain is subjective" yes but we can all agree that some things hurt more 
than others. 

"You don't think it is as advised to give birth while drugged" 90% of 
modern births are drugged, and everyone seems to turn out fine for the most 
part. Honestly I don't see why you would want to do it naturally, and for 
the sake of argument, if the option is there, you can't say "well I did it 
without drugs, so therefore it hurts more" and refuse. 

"That area.... if you will, rips while giving birth. I can to a certain 
extent compare that to certain types of pain that I have/can experience/d. 
I would imagine it would be similar to skin being pulled apart, but on a 
larger more sensitive scale. (correct me if I'm wrong). However, getting 
hit in the junk is a pain that is unrelatable to any other kind. It is a 
sickening internal pain. It doesn't feel like a punch to the shoulder or a 
cut from something sharp. Also realize that the body does everything it can 
to tell your conscious mind that hitting that area is a VERY bad thing. 
More or less the existence of the human race. So if that area is damaged, 
giving a huge shockwave of pain is how it lets us know to stop doing what 
it is we are doing.

Don't feel like I'm trying to make childbirth sound easy. Absolutely not 
what I'm trying to say. But I've broken my nose on a metal pole before, and 
that pain was nothing compared to a good shot to the groin.

comments.text:
+Károly Németh
 "Protecting sides"

No, attacking bullshit.
I responded specifically because OP stated a blatant falsehood that caught 
my eye and several ignoramuses thought it fit to thumb this bullshit up, so 
I refuted it.

"For example Exgrmbl, you given me a link of nothing,"
It is not nothing. Every study conducted on the topic shows what I said. 
You are of course right when you point out that there are flaws and that 
such things are hard to measure - especially since things like 
socialisation can't really be considered. Still, it's the best we have.

" and say that man was made more stubborn so he could stand more of what 
comes, but if its stronger, than is it really fair?
Woman does not have those bones, and those muscles,"

I understand that your point is about relative vs. absolute, but how would 
you measure the former?
The point was to demonstrate, that even if there were no studies on the 
topic - from an evolutionary and biological perspective, every different 
aspect of our bodies implies the exact opposite to that what OP claimed.

"than again how will that make men better in this case?"

Men are not "better", that's not the point.
Let me demonstrate by simply giving you a parallel in biology:
Men in general, are stronger, absolute.
Relative to body weight/muscemass/fat however, men are no longer stronger.
The same might be true for pain perception - men's pain response to a 
constant exerted force is, in absolute, less intense than women's - but as 
you note, it might be the case that the difference would be marginal or 
non-existent if we could adjust for women's less robust build.
The evidence contrary to that speculation however, is that hormonal 
differences might still make a significant difference, since there is good 
evidence to suggest that testosterone enhances men's pain tolerance.

"men just cant accept the fact that women can handle more pain"

No, you need to learn about biology and sexual dimorphism.
A simple google search about the perception of pain in males and females 
should give you the insight that your claim is in fact the opposite of 
reality.
https://www.google.com/search?q=perception+of+pain+in+males+and+females&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&aq=t&rls=org.mozilla:de:official&client=firefox-a&channel=rcs
Here, click it. Do it. You might learn something.

But really, common sense should suffice, consider this:
men are larger
men have stronger, denser bones
men have a more robust skeletal structure and joints
men have bigger extremities.
men have thicker skin
men have more musclemass
The average male has twice the upper body strength to that of a female.
Take note of these differences in the sexes. The next thing is to ask 
yourself the question why that might be, what evolutionary pressure was 
involved that lead to the expression of these qualities.

Somehow you manage to think that it makes sense to postulate that the more 
robust part of the human species would be more receptive to pain, when all 
the aforementioned attributes of their bodies alone build them to withstand 
bigger mechanical stresses and exertions of force.

Wishful thinking. Naturally, I thumbed-down this display of idiocy.

initial impact. Also, you still seem to think that the purpose of the

comments.text:
+Metalchemist2 It's also not likely that one will die during childbirth. 
There is a maternal death rate of approximately 0.5192 percent globally, 
taken from the birth rate (converted to births per day) in the CIA's World 
Factbook and Table 10 in Volume 61, Number 4 of the National Vital 
Statistics Reports (NVSS) in 2010. It's even lower in first-world countries 
in particular. The US (as an arbitrary choice for a first-world country) 
has a rate of maternal death of around 0.01846 percent (i.e., on average, 
one in 5,416 women going through childbirth in the US die). The data is 
from the website for Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and 
Volume 62, Number 9 of the NVSS. However, as mentioned in a different 
comment thread, death is not a measurement of pain. You can die with no 
pain at all, so it's pretty irrelevant here.

As a side note, the testes are actually in the sac so they can remain cool; 
it preserves the sperm, since they begin to die when the surrounding 
temperature exceeds a certain point. That's if I remember correctly, at 
least.

Edit: I was partially right. The testes are located away from the body 
because their optimal temperature is slightly less than the core body 
temperature, not just because the sperm can die above that temperature.

"but we are talking about the moment"

I'm 100% disagree with this thought.

I understand that some people are trying to make an comparison, but...which 
moment of the childbirth we take? When it begins, when it is finished? The 
fact it's that a childbirth takes a longer time and that contributes a lot 
to the pain that someone feels. You can't take a random second of a 
childbirth and compare it with the moment when you get kicked in the balls 
and say "that both are equally painful". It's like to compare the pain when 
your kick something hard with your toe with the pain of breaking a bone. 
Maybe in the moment both are equally painfull, but no one would say "it's 
the same pain". Everybody would be agree that breaking an arm is much more 
painful because we also take in count the time. 

So I will make this question: Why we don't do take the time in count in 
this case? Why we only take a moment? By those standars we can say a lot of 
crazy things, like falling from the stairs is equally painfull to a 
childbirth or that cutting your finger with a paper is equally painfull 
that a kick in the balls. This is what happens when you compare apples with 
oranges? No this is what happen when you compare apples with elves.

And second, why some guys make this kind of discussion a battle of sexes? 
OK guys, you feel more pain. No let's go to a corner and began to sing "We 
are tha campions"! It's like to make a contest about who is the most 
idiotic-stinky-ugly-person, get the 1st prize and being happy with that!

comments.text:
+Squiddy Gurl First of all, in mammals, birthing pain is automatically 
lessened by the release of natural pain killers in the brain (oxytocin). 
Sure, it's still painful, but not as much as it could be. As the baby 
prepares for birth, it releases chemicals into the mother's blood stream 
that activate this system, as well as the uterine contractions and cervical 
dialation. So a woman's body has time to prepare for birth. A man does not 
have that luxury before getting kicked in the balls. 

Ever stubbed you toe really hard? Remember how much it hurt? Try stubbing 
it hard enough that you break both your toe and the table leg you stubbed 
it on. Now imagine it's not just your toe that hurts, it a pain shooting 
trough your body (parasympathetic nervous system, I believe). No time for 
the oxytocin to set in or an epidural to be given. You're writhing in pain 
just like a man is when he gets kicked in the balls. 



Secondly, be thankful your ovaries are inside your body and not hanging out 
there to get kicked. At least they are protected by being inside your own 
body along with a layer of muscle and tissue. Because Testes need a 
slightly cooler temperature to produce sperm, our vital reproductive organs 
are left hanging on a thin flab of skin that raunchy men refer to as the 
"dick". When you get kicked in the dick, it's not like like your taking a 
Go Ju Ryu kick in the right stomach. You are actually getting kicked RIGHT 
IN THE ORGANS. 



Seriously, if giving birth is like having a watermelon crammed up you anus, 
getting kicked in the balls is like getting that water melon crammed up 
your urethra at lightning speed. Only about 10x worse since it's not 
natural to take a low blow right in the sac, so the body doesn't release 
the oxytocin I mentioned earlier. It may not last as long, but the few 
minutes after being kicked in the balls will be the worst of your life.

comments.text:
+EpicRainbowLollipop
Alright. I'm going to number these so you know what 'paragraph' of yours 
that I'm responding to, just to make things easier to read. So, '1. -----' 
would be regarding your first paragraph section thing.

1. While I did say that, it's just to make things fair. I'm still comparing 
what we're trying to compare, just over different periods of time. And even 
so, the amount of time a guy is in pain would probably add up to be quite a 
few hours, putting the amount of pain from child birth and the amount of 
pain from being kicked in the balls at an equal starting point, 
duration-wise. That's simply to stop people from saying "Child birth is 
worse 'cause it lasts longer!". You can't do that. You have to look at the 
big picture while sticking to the 2 things being compared.

2. Refer to 1. However, if you want to give women that huge advantage (or 
disadvantage, really), then yes. Birthing one child would probably be worse 
than getting kicked in the balls, under most circumstances.

3. Alright. While the period may be related, it's still not the same thing, 
so stop trying to say women have it worse because of that. I don't care as 
I'm comparing the pain from child birth and kick in the balls. NOT a period.

HOWEVER, if you want to compare one menstrual cycle and one kick in the 
balls, I'd probably put those at the same level of ouch. They both can, 
depending on the individual, cause abdominal cramps, major pain, nausea, 
among other things. There's one big difference between the two, if we're 
not counting the amount of time they last. The menstrual cycle keeps a 
woman healthy and ready for child birth, but being kicked in the balls 
could stop a man from being able to produce children. Though on a 
physically painful point, they're probably about even, if we don't consider 
frequency.

4. Men can't keep their balls safe. I mean, what are we gonna do; wear 
uncomfortable and ineffective cups all day, every day? Don't think so. As 
for circumcision, that's nowhere near a fair argument for either side as 
most guys are forced into being circumcised (in the US anyway) before they 
can even think! However, if that's the case, we don't remember the pain 
from it, so it doesn't matter. Therefore, that's not something you can use 
as comparison as we can't even remember it happening.

As for the last sentence about *kicks*, there's no reason we should be 
directly using kicks other than for simplicity's sake. Kick should refer to 
any painful impact to the balls. If we only use kicks, then we're talking 
about dumbasses who think they know how to kick properly, but miss the 
balls and typically cause little to no pain whatsoever, so the pain isn't 
even comparable. However, taking a baseball bat to the balls will be the 
worst pain a guy will ever experience. There's many variables that have to 
be taken into account. And yes, there's plenty for the woman's side, as 
well.

5. That's completely true. However, if you're gonna try to compare the two 
for some reason, you have to at least look at the big picture and be

comments.text:
+YukI9689 Okay, fair point. I agree that what i've said previously 
shouldn't be considered regarding your argument, but I only brought up the 
topic of periods because you started talking about how men will take many 
blows to their balls throughout their life. 

I thought we were comparing one time a woman goes through childbirth with a 
man getting one kick in the balls.

I'm just saying that the menstrual cycle and childbirth are both closely 
related things, and that while it's fair enough to say that not all women 
go through childbirth, periods are inevitable for an average healthy woman 
(and women who go through childbirth will obviously go through periods!)). 
And again, I'm not talking about all women, but *some* really do experience 
major cramps, nausea, cold sweats and diarrhoea, and possibly other things 
which are far worse and beyond what I can imagine.

Men on the other hand, are given the option to keep their balls safe, and 
if not for their religion or beliefs, they don't have to go through 
circumcision (here you go, it's that "something" you wanted for the male 
side) and go through the pain there. I know that there are everyday 
accidents where your balls could get hurt, but unless you're really that 
vulnerable, you probably won't experience major *kicks* to the balls.

*I'm just going to reinforce my point again, but I don't think there's 
anyway you can compare the two things because everybody feels pain 
differently.*

compared. We're comparing the pain of child birth and being kicked in the

to be something thrown in on the male side, too.

I mean, think of it this way;
If I compared chocolate ice cream and vanilla ice cream, you wouldn't say 
"But vanilla ice cream with a banana should be considered, too!" because 
that's not what we're comparing. We're talking about ice cream; bananas 
don't apply.

Same goes for this. The period =/= child birth pain. The period =/= kick in 
the balls. Therefore, periods should not be considered.

fact that child birth is a natural occurrence and is meant to happen for 
the survival of the human race. because of that, women are most likely 
developed to tolerate it more. it could be that the pain otherwise would be 
much more severe, but through necessity women can tolerate it to the point 
where it doesn't hurt as much as it should. that's not to say it doesn't 
hurt, just that the way women are made makes it hurt less than it otherwise 
would. men, on the other hand, aren't meant to get kicked or otherwise hurt 
in the nuts. because of this, men haven't naturally adapted to the pain it 
causes, and therefore feel the full thing. it goes with the fact that every 
person feels pain differently. because child birth is natural, women have 
adapted to handle it much better, and therefore it doesn't hurt as much as 
it should. getting kicked in the nuts isn't natural, so men haven't adapted 
to handle it, and therefore the pain is tolerated much less. in relativity,

captions.text:
In the battle of the sexes we are 
fiercely divided, who has a worse when it
comes to pain?

On the one hand women are left with the
task of fitting a watermelon sized

object through a coin sized hole.  On the
other hand, males protest that even the

slightest nick of their family jewels
can leave them incapacitated.
So which hurts more, childbirth or getting kicked in the balls?

Before we begin there is a rumor that is
circulating the internet claiming that

the human body can take up to 45
del units of pain and yet a mother feels

up to 57 del of pain during
childbirth,

which is apparently equivalent to 20
bones being fractured at once.

The claim then goes on to suggest that
being kicked in the balls brings more

than 9000 del of pain.  Now
apart from the absurd logic that both of

these events can surpass the alleged
human limit it, actually uses a unit of

pain, the del, which doesn't even exist.
There is a unit of pain once devised

called the dol, from the latin word for
pain "dolor" but we will discuss this later.

To really evaluate this question we
first need to understand what pain is,
which isn't an easy task.

There is actually a group of specialized
nerve cells in your body called nociceptors
that react to pain.

Unlike other nerves which readily fire in
response to normal touch or temperature,

nociceptors will only fire once a certain
pain threshold has been passed.  Some of

these nociceptors respond quickly sending
signals to the spinal cord and brain
which produce sharp and sudden pain, allowing you to react quickly

while others transmit more slowly and are
responsible for the prolonged dull

ache you feel.  For males, testicles are
internal organs that have migrated out

of the body cavity which we explain in
a previous video you can check out here.

And well some internal organs such as
the liver feel no pain, others like the

testicles are covered with many 
nociceptors making them extremely sensitive.
Afterall their well-being is of the utmost importance.

Furthermore the testicles are attached
to many nerves in the stomach as well as

the vagus is nerve which is directly
connected to the brains vomit center,

and this is why when hit the pain spreads
throughout the abdomen.

The fact that testicles have minimal
protection only strengthens the

accompanying symptoms of nausea, increased
blood pressure, heart rate and sweating.

But not so fast gentlemen, even though
childbirth may not be facing a direct

blow to any internal organs, the
mechanical distension of the uterine

area also triggers nociceptors and
causes the same kind of visceral pain.

Also consider that throughout evolution
female human hips have become smaller

while babies heads have become
larger.  And not to mention labor lasts

8 hours on average with a mixture of
nausea, fatigue and pain.

On top of it all, tension and stretching
of muscle and tissue increase as labour

intensifies creating sharp and localized
pain.

Okay, so both obviously hurt and have a
lot of mechanical stimulation sending
signals to the pain centers of the brain.

But this is where it gets tricky, because
the pain isn't simply a physical

response but rather a partially
perceptive or subjective experience.

This means that every single individual
perceives pain in a slightly different

way.  And not only between individuals but
depending on your mood, alertness or even

previous experience pain may affect
you differently.

It's for this reason that so many
attempts to objectively measure pain have

failed including the dol system which
we mentioned earlier.

Interestingly nearly 80% of
upper limb amputees experience a
phenomenon known as "phantom limb pain".

That is they feel pain in a limb that is
no longer there.  And while little is

understood about the mechanism for the
pain, it is clear that there is no

particular input to trigger the response
and yet they still feel a very real
pain.

As such pain is not a stimulus it is an
experience that is different for

everybody.  Suffice to say both instances
of childbirth and getting hit in the
balls can hurt alot.

So we call this one at tie, apart from
the fact that the experiences are

completely different and there is so many
variables to consider.

In some instances a man could
experience more pain than his female

counterpart and vice versa.  The main
difference being one results in a newborn

baby, while the other potentially
results in a decreased the chance of
having one.

title: Childbirth vs Getting Kicked in the Balls
